tremb 20-Apr-21 10:49 PM
<Wrenkit> - Featherkit - current The pale sun was beginning to climb towards the treetops, the air echoing with birdsong. The dawn patrol had left, and slowly the warriors and apprentices of ThunderClan began to stir, preparing for their duties. Dark amber hues flew open at the very first sounds of activity, and Wrenkit scrambled rather clumsily from her nest inside the nursery. Moss still clinging to her brown and cream pelt, she made her debut into the camp clearing. She was typically one of the first kits out of the nursery in the mornings, as early morning time was her absolute favorite. There was just something about the crisp morning air, and the way the sun lit the trees up golden but had yet to bathe the camp in its light. And quite honestly, Wrenkit loved observing the warriors and apprentices as they went about their tasks. She sat silently outside of the nursery, head tipped to the side as her clanmates formed together into patrols and made their way out of the camp, eavesdropping on their chit chat. She listened as apprentices were instructed to fetch fresh bedding for the elders, and the objections of those chosen to check for ticks. The young kitten giggled softly to herself. At just over four moons old, Wrenkit still had a ways to go before she would become an apprentice, but like most kits, she was unbelievably excited to reach her sixth moon. Even the less enjoyable tasks such as ridding the elders of ticks and fetching bedding for them seemed fun for Wrenkit. She couldn’t wait to contribute to her clan. She would be the best, most well behaved apprentice the clan had ever seen! If she could keep her focus, of course. She never could seem to entertain one thing for too long without getting side tracked. Realizing her pelt was still covered in clumps of moss, she began to groom herself, though she never took her eyes off of her surroundings as she did so. Being in camp was so mundane, she had to keep herself entertained somehow.
@frost
peri™ 21-Apr-21 04:28 PM
She had grown used to it by now; she had been teetering on the edge of sleep for her entire life and this was simply the climax of it all: nightmares. She didn’t understand them, didn’t care to understand them, even, and yet on the same side of the coin she had wondered why. It was as if in wonderment that she had wondered why they were there; why they had stayed for so long without leaving for even a day. It shook her up every single time. There were no reason for them, not that she could think of. Except for one: the ghosts of her past. How she had wanted to outrun them, had wanted to get away from them, but there they were. At every corner. Forcing her to relive them even if she didn’t want to. They were insidious, mystifying and intimidating, and, to put it bluntly: she wanted them gone. A name for a name, it seemed. Lavendercloud. What a wonderful name that was; so graceful and lively and a name that reminded her of a caprioling breeze on an open field. ”Lavendercloud,” she tested the name on her tongue, lips opening into a bright smile. ”Well, it’s lovely to meet you, you know,” tufted ears flicked. ”The nursery?” she queried as they walked on, clearly curious. ”Would it be safe for me to assume that you’re a queen, then? And, if so, what are the kits’ names?” Her breath caught in her throat, heart rate quickening: embarrassment. ”Sorry for so many questions, Lav. I’m the curious type, you could say.” blurryowl & lavendercloud | sleepless in seattle | @lynn (sorry for the wait agh. next replies should come much quicker!)
cake 22-Apr-21 03:18 PM
FRICK) (edited)
marbledpaw | @Shade (I TAGGED THE WRONG PERSON TOO BAHAHA IM SORRY PRIM)
Okay, easy. Head high, tail lifted, smile- set on making an acquaintance at least, Marbledpaw ran Finchbriar's instructions over in her head once, tail flicking. And- there! Pale violet gaze shifted upwards something she had first dismissed as a falling leaf seized her attention, ears perking and paw lifting in protest.
Managing to crawl up behind the apprentice, the little calico watched carefully, blinking as she assessed her situation. Maybe she should've just left her alone, but eventually her curiosity piqued after watching Tigerpaw for a few seconds and she quickly followed suit: it seemed like the leader's den was her main goal.
Marbledpaw piped up behind the brown tabby, poking her lightly. "I think the den's off limits, she suggested, tipping her head to the side.
And you're squatting like a duck. She was tempted to add, but kept the temptation to flaunt her superiority away from the younger apprentice- she was just barely older, but that counted as something, didn't it?
 (edited)
prim 24-Apr-21 11:06 AM
{Laurelblaze} | Gathering
The full moon had made it’s ascent into the starry night sky, illuminating the territories of the clan in it’s bright, silver light. The night of the Gathering was upon them, and they needed to make their way over to the island post-haste. Stepping into the clearing, the tortoiseshell deputy cleared her throat before she addressed her clanmates. ”Let all cats who are old enough to catch their own prey join me at the Gathering!” she called out to her clanmates with a deep, loud cry, before she began to make her way towards the camp entrance. Like every other clan, they were required to attend, so she didn’t want to be ridiculously late to the whole affair. @ThunderClan
prim 25-Apr-21 12:39 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Blurryowl | past III | repost
She wasn’t going to be heading out into the territory in this mess. Laurelblaze didn’t like cold showers, and the mud that clung to her paws like stubborn, spiky burrs caught in her fur if she passed by a bramble bush. Except it was caked on earth and it was gross and uncomfortable to pick out of her fur or to wash it off. Especially on her large paws, they were magnets for the substance. Luckily she was staying in camp for the day, it was the patrols’ problem now. They’ll probably come back soon anyways, it’ll be a washout anyways. We’ll have to remark the border later on. What a hassle. she let out a small sigh at the thought, more work to handle later, at least until the rainstorm passed. The deputy would have to worry about that later, no use whining about it, it wasn’t like marking a border took too much effort. ”Yeah, wouldn’t want to get caught in a downpour,” she mused aloud, staring up at the gray skies. More raindrops fell nearby, staining the sand-colored soil nearby with dark beige impact circles. It wasn’t too intense yet, but she still was paying careful attention to it. ”I’m doing well, the kits I adopted with Hollyfrost seem to be settling in a bit... I think. Some of them can be a bit of a pawful.” she grinned awkwardly at the thought, they were a stubborn bunch, reminded her of herself when she was at their age. As she spoke, the rain seemed to increase in intensity, more and more droplets falling from the sky and hitting the ground in rapid succession.
”We should probably continue this conversation under one of the enclaves so we don’t get all soggy.” she chuckled quietly, just before a large raindrop hit her on the muzzle, causing her to recoil from the impact. She shook her head quickly, letting out a small huff before she began to make her way towards one of the more sheltered areas of the camp. Laurelblaze wasn’t going to hide in the warriors den, she wanted to stay outside in camp, get some fresh air at least. The large tortoiseshell glanced up to see one of the outcroppings of stone jutting out from the side of the camp’s walls. It would provide an ample shelter from the rain for the two of them. Taking note of this, the deputy sat down and began to relax as she waited for Blurryowl to join her. This beat standing out there waiting for the rain to soak her fur. @peri™
cake 27-Apr-21 12:39 PM
marbledpaw | @prim
"Good point," she agreed, still looking a little conscious and a warm flush retaining its orangey glow on her cheeks. She wished for a second she still retained the kithood confidence that had seemed to drain slowly out after Hazelhues passed until it was just barely here. Marbledpaw straightened up, ears perking, nodding as if she was handed out an assignment. "I think I'll try it out sometime soon," she said firmly, downy pelt clearly ruffled and her expression slightly foul as she imagined the possibility of failure.
Too naive to understand that Finchbriar's advice could be painfully wrong, there was a new, determined skip in her step when she paced. She didn't expect good luck wishes, so instead raised her tail and instead tried to pick out her mentor so she could nag about going outside. "Thank you~"

aspenpaw | snowstorm | present @Scribl The first thing Aspenpaw noticed once she emerged from the apprentice den was that the ground was cold and wet. Inwardly sighing, she rolled her eyes. The weather had been less than ideal lately. Lifting her paws more carefully, as to avoid mud pools, she continued towards the center of camp, and towards her mentor, Snowstorm. The tall apprentice dipped her head in greeting towards the warrior despite her mood, which corresponded perfectly with the weather. ”Greetings. What’s on the agenda today?” The she-cat’s brown tabby fur fluffed up in response to the chill occupying the territory. Her tall ears flicked back as a lone drop of rain splashed on her black nose. Stifling a groan, the apprentice began to groom her slightly dampened fur. It seemed there was a light misting emerging from the clouds. Just perfect.
Scribl 27-Apr-21 04:27 PM
Snowstorm | Aspenpaw | Present @lynn Snowstorm realized the weather was bad enough today to make his thick white pelt seem to be useless. He responded to Aspenpaw, "Today, we will try to make the best of our time by hunting. I could let you practice fighting moves, but I don't want the Clan to starve, especially in this horrid weather, and you know what happens at Gatherings when there is a shortage of prey." As the rain landed on Snowstorm's white pelt, he fluffed it out and shook himself dry. "Well then, why are you waiting...let's go hunting before we look like half-drowned mice." (edited)

peri™ 27-Apr-21 07:53 PM
In all honesty, she probably would still be out in the territory had the rain not come when it did. She couldn’t say she blamed Laurelblaze, though; walking in the rain was not for everyone, and she knew that as well as anyone else. How they spent their time was their business and she wasn’t about to intrude on that. Turning her multi-hued gaze to the sky again, a scowl painted her features as she noted just how dismal it looked. StarClan, it was worse than she thought. At Laurelblaze’s musings, she flicked a tufted ear, smiling. ”I feel bad for anyone who’s still out in that,” she purred with another great smile. At the deputy’s comment on kits, her tail flicked behind her. ”Oh, yes! It’s good that they’re settling in, then,” another purr left her gullet, her head tilting. ”And, yeah. Kits can be a pawful for sure. I’m sure I was quite the pawful when I was a kit,” the joke left her lips without second thought as she maneuvered behind Laurelblaze to get to the nearest enclave. She had to say, this was something to cross off of her bucket list. If she even had one. ”Weather is much worse than I thought,” she murmured, mostly to herself as she sat down, curling her tail around her paws, curious to see where the conversation would head next. blurryowl & laurelblaze | the devils in the details | @prim
prim 27-Apr-21 11:58 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Blurryowl | past III
She wouldn’t want to trade places with anyone caught in the rain, that was for sure. She might have ended up coming home looking like a mess, muddy fur, debris clinging to her pelt, it wouldn’t have been pretty. Not that she was one to care for beauty standards and all that, but even she thought she would look absolutely horrid. They might think she was a swamp monster that crawled it’s way out of the marshes from ShadowClan’s territory, and she wouldn’t blame them for that. She might have looked twice if she saw some bedraggled creature like that waltzing it’s way into their camp, not that swamp monsters were real or anything. That was silly, monsters only ran down Thunderpaths. ”Heh, if you think that was bad, I kept trying to escape when I was their age. Except instead of devising a mousebrained plan of leaving entirely, I just wanted to see the territory.” she snickered quietly, looking back on her times as a kit. She always had that little brand of fire within her, wanting to take on the world by herself. Little Laurelkit would never have thought her life would make so many twists and turns, and where she ended up now. Naïve yet willing to take on any form of danger, no matter how daunting, she was always brave. A little too much back then, but it served her well nowadays. Maybe her kits would look back on this and realize the same, or have a feeling akin to it. Everyone grew up eventually, she just hoped they learned to adjust to the life of the clan soon enough. She already was attached to them, she’d protect them with her life. ”Kits are so silly, though, they always think they’re as big as the warriors, it’s cute.” @peri™
Springy 🦤 30-Apr-21 03:16 PM
Marigoldpaw - Icestar - A Fruitful Trip - Past II His milk-tipped ears perked at  the words.  ”I am?” he said.  Marigoldpaw was surprised by what was said, to say the least.  How could he be good company?  He never thought that if he was a different cat and got stuck with a cat like him that he would enjoy it much.  He was awkward, quiet, and not exactly the best at coming up with clear and confident words to share with others.  A small, sheepishly flattered smile spread across his expression.  ”Thanks… you’re good company too,” he said, his smile strengthening as he aimed it towards her.  Honestly, Marigoldpaw hadn’t been the most sure about this small trip when he was first offered the opportunity.  Icestar was intimidating, after all, and it was hard to feel completely normal around her when you were aware that she had a higher place in the clan.  Not only that, but Marigoldpaw knew that Icestar meant business, and the last thing he wanted to do was risk offending or aggravating her.       He had no clue how he hadn’t managed to do so yet, although the fact that he had been, and still was, going well made him feel more comfortable.  He had mainly forgotten the whole leaving-camp-against-the-rules situation by now, and felt more relaxed and less stressed being by Icestar.  She wasn’t too scary, right?  It didn’t seem so after this, but there was still no way that he was going to try and risk being rude or disrespectful to her or any other cat in the clan.  Basically, he felt a little more inclined to treat Icestar like he would normally treat any other cat now, not that he would forget the fact that she was still his leader.
-     The soft bristling of the bare branches dragged his attention back to the present.  Briefly looking over the grey-brown and white surroundings, he reminded himself of what they were doing and where they were.  They were about to head back to camp, so he had to prepare to dodge trees and make his pawsteps as quiet as possible.  That way he wouldn’t be heard by any unwanted ears, although he wasn’t completely sure that it would do any help, as he couldn’t cover up his scent without doing too much unnecessary backtracking.  He was with Icestar, anyways.  He should be alright with her.  What rogue would dare attack a leader?  Although, larger animals might still be a problem… no, they were alright.  They just had to head back as they did before and nothing would happen.  He’d done this what seemed to be a thousand times already and nothing bad had happened.  Shaking himself as if to rid his fur of the stress his mind was actively providing, he officially went back to his own unsure reality.  One thing that he wasn’t unsure of, though, was that he was steadily gaining a friend.
peri™ 03-May-21 02:53 PM
As much as the she-cat wouldn’t like to admit it, growing up was hard for her. Perhaps it was the simple thought of responsibility that made her rue it all, or perhaps it was something more. Was it simply the fact that growing up meant that she was closer to death? As silly as that may sound, it might be half-true. For her entire life, she had never taken news of death easily, often secluding herself to somewhere just so that she could be alone. StarClan only knows how she would react when her time had finally come. She didn’t want to think about it. At the deputy’s story, Blurryowl let go a sharp and light laugh: the skip of fish in a lake. She had been like that, too. It was always fun to meet people who were similar to you: kindred spirits, they called it. ”Believe it or not, I was the same way: I had always wanted to leave the camp, wanted to see what the territory had to offer. But my parents never let me. And then when I became a warrior, I’ve been taking advantage of it ever since,” she purred in response, delving into a story of her own. ”They really are. To be honest, I do miss being a kit sometimes, to be free of responsibilities.” she was only half joking, of course. blurryowl & laurelblaze | the devil’s in the details | @prim

prim 03-May-21 05:26 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Blurryowl | past III
Indeed, childhood was a time that flew by rather quickly. It barely prepared them for the realities of an adult world, and the responsibilities that were thrown upon their little shoulders. Going from playing mossball one day to learning how to prevent themselves from getting killed in battle... It was a stark contrast from the life they knew before. It was the reality for everyone out here, not just clan cats. They all grew up and had to learn how to survive in this harsh environment. It was all that they could do, besides begging some Twoleg for food and becoming their plaything. She refused to submit to that sort of lifestyle, the woods was her hunting grounds, the place she felt most at ease. Perhaps, her kit self knew this too, that it was where she belonged. ”I used to daydream about running through the trees, hopping from branch to branch. I also imagined myself taking on so many beasts at once, battling them out one by one.” she chuckled quietly, while she knew the feeling of the first thought well, the second one was a bit far-fetched, even for a warrior of her strength. The tortoiseshell was powerful, but she didn’t have some form of divine strength on her side. She too was mortal, she too had her weaknesses and flaws. Like any other warrior, she too could be struck down if she wasn’t careful. When she was young, she didn’t understand that, she thought every warrior was unstoppable. She came to learn that it wasn’t the case very quickly. Such a bleak subject, let’s get back to talking about the cute stuff we did as kits! ”I miss it, I always talked about conquering the world with my brothers. Especially with my brother Jasper, it was such a simpler time. Still, I’m fond of it.” @peri™

Shade 04-May-21 05:33 PM
"Bah!" a shrill, throaty yelp of surprise burst from the apprentice as she jumped and spun to meet the source of a sudden voice. What she found was a pair of arresting violet eyes, a sleek tortoiseshell pelt, and a judgmentally pursed mouth. Thick as her skull was, though, even Tigerpaw could see the hint of curiosity mixed in with her clanmate's freezing eyes. How did I not smell you? The question played clear as day in her own coral facets. Instead of chasing the answer though, Tigerpaw skipped straight ahead to trying to play off her bad behavior. "I was- um-" Her brown tabby pelt bristled and her eyes glittered as she fumbled wildly for an explanation. "I was getting moss for Icestar's nest-" One look at her empty paws and she regretted the lie instantly. "Wait, no, I mean-" Exasperation began to boil inside her like magma. Springy 🦤 04-May-21 07:10 PM
Marigolddust - Tigerpaw - Near Future The juicy taste of fresh prey warmed Marigolddust as he took another bite of the bluejay lying at his paws.  Next to him lay a long blue, white, and black feather.  It had become a habit of his to take a feather from every winged meal he had.  They always made his nest feel more homey and gave it a little more color and variety.  He’d yet to get a bluejay feather, and when he spotted the bird in the prey pile that morning he couldn’t help but get excited.  Now, he enjoyed the meal and kept the feather tucked partially underneath him to avoid risking the wind carrying it off into the air.       The day was peaceful even before he caught sight of the distinct blue prey in the pile of fur and feathers.  The sun was uncovered by any clouds that might have otherwise blanketed up it’s sunny rays, and the grass was no longer covered in snow.  The green hues of the new leaves on the trees seemed to glow under the strong light that the sun provided, bristling softly against one another as gentle, warm breezes pushed and pulled at them.  There were bird tweets in the distance, blessing his ears with the beautiful songs.  He kept himself occupied by watching the cats in the camp pass by and converse with one another.  His thoughts were quite calm for once.  He hadn’t had much interaction yet that day, besides a good-morning greeting with Fernpaw before leaving to be surrounded by all of these other cats, some of them still strangers to him.       Releasing a relaxed sigh, he set his head down on his paws and enjoyed the warm feeling of the sun’s heat and the occasional bristling of his fur when a downcasted wind brushed past.  It was a nice, peaceful day today, and he enjoyed the quiet that had settled on his thoughts today…
@Shade Sorry, got distracted!))

Springy 🦤 05-May-21 07:54 PM
Marigolddust - Cinnamonpaw - Current The scent of herbs had filled his senses completely as soon as he woke up, making the transition from sleep to consciousness sharp.  He was used to it by now, and no longer got headaches from it as he had when he first started getting used to the welcome of the morning.  It didn’t take long for him to find himself out and into the camp, taking in the warmer sunlight of the new-leaf.  He was far more fond of this season than he was of the previous one.  He never did gather enough guts to try sliding on the ice- on purpose, that is- or having a snowball fight with anybody else in the clan.  But, although he hadn’t experienced any of the average leaf-bare fun, he was already convinced that he enjoyed collecting flowers and herbs with Fernpaw better.  Flowers weren’t dangerous, anyhow, and danger always made things stressful in his eyes.       The young warrior let his lemony gaze wander around camp, not quite sure what he should do.  Should he hunt?  Patrol?  He didn’t exactly feel like doing either.  Although, he felt that way every day, so perhaps he should actually give it a try some time.  That way he could rid himself of the horrid feeling of guilt when he didn’t feel useful and the feeling of fear at the thought of actually doing something.  With his dark grey fur absorbing the warmth of the sunlight of the new day he felt groggy and lazy.  Warrior’s weren’t supposed to be lazy… but perhaps he could take a few moments to himself, just to not focus so much on the world outside of camp and anything else that might cause him to stress.  Sauntering over to the side of the camp, he laid down, leaning against the rocky walls of the camp.
@heresthetea
Shade 06-May-21 11:55 PM
Precarious as the soot and silver warrior was in his guardianship of the feather, a spritely breeze picked up, sweeping dust off the camp floor and funneling feathers from under paws with it. Sand and quill swirled away for what seemed like a permanent farewell. It would have been if not for Tigerpaw. Feather on the loose! Her pink-red eyes widened as the blue plumage soared above her. Instantly the young she-cat's gaze was marked with a focused excitement, and her muscles not far behind. In a twitch she was flying up in pursuit of it and hooked a chocolate mit in the path of the runaway, slapping it back to the ground. After quickly checking to make sure it'd held its shape, Tigerpaw nipped up the knick-knack and trotted over to Marigolddust. She set it before the timid warrior and dipped her head. "I never knew blue jays could still fly after being eaten," she joked in greeting, a contagious smile curling on her lips. @Springy 🦤
prim 08-May-21 07:19 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Sorrelpaw | present
The sun’s rays cast a golden sheen upon the camp in patches, shining through clumps of lime-green pollen and juvenile leaves. While the mornings were typically quiet for ThunderClan, today seemed to be an exception. She could see more and more cats in the clearing, though it made sense. The days were getting longer, daylight was emerging even in the earliest hours of dawn. It provided a silent wake-up-call to the rest of ThunderClan— it’s daytime, time to get to work. Though for Laurelblaze, she never had any trouble getting up early. She always was a morning person. Early bird catches the worm. a mantra she often repeated to herself whenever she arose from her nest. Her apprentices hated her for waking them up at such StarClan-forsaken hours, though she’d hold off for now. Tigerpaw and Bouncepaw each deserved their rest after all the training she put them through. The ThunderClan deputy had a lot of expectations set for herself and by others. She wanted to be a paragon of a warrior, a role model for the kits and apprentices to follow. A future leader who could command respect from every single one of her warriors, as well as being the right-hand of her leader. The russet-toned tortoiseshell pushed herself each and every single day, often to the point of exhaustion. She had to serve her clan to the utmost degree, providing stability and protection in the most dire of times. Everything she did was for the betterment of ThunderClan. Her clan was practically her family, and it included her kits and kin.
She rose up from the divot in the ground under the branches of a fallen beech tree, shaking out her thick, mottled pelt of patches of ginger, russet, and white. Twin hues of honey-amber and sea-blue were narrowed as the sun shined it’s blinding white light into her line of sight, momentarily opening once she’d regained her vision. The deputy let out a rather significant yawn, exposing her large, pearly fangs to the world around her— though if she didn’t admit that she exaggerated her motions a bit, she’d be lying. She liked to imagine she was a lion emerging into the sun, baring her teeth to the world and bowing to no one. Just her being flashy, nothing more, Laurelblaze just wanted to do that for kicks. Once she was finished with her dramatic display of her might, she stretched out her stiffened limbs that still felt atrophied from her hours of slumber. Once she felt them crack, a sign they were reinvigorated with energy in her eyes, she let out a pleased sigh as she stood back up— her bushy tail waving around behind her excitedly. Now, she was ready to take on the day. @faerielights ♡
faerielights ♡ 08-May-21 07:34 PM
sorrelpaw & laurelblaze The lengths of the days were becoming longer, and the warmth in the air held a hint of what was to come later on. As the seasons continued to change, their impacts were left quite obvious - almost as a non-physical scar upon the ground. The plants that were once dead were now seeming to pop back into place, reinvigorated with the coming seasons of warmth and heat. The change was rather dramatic, however. Some days bordered on cold, whilst others were hot or humid - it was always a gamble on what was to come as the season change disliked being predictable. A certain calico apprentice seemed rather disinterested in this change, however, and merely resorted to lounging in the clearing as she had no current tasks. Her long cheek fur was splayed around her paws, too long to fully keep off of the ground. It was rather annoying keeping the fur clean at times, but the apprentice seemed to do whatever she could to look her absolute best for those around her. She had high hopes that one day someone would fall in love with how gorgeous she was, and fawn after her like a love-sick kitten. That had yet to happen though, so Sorrelpaw just resorted to dreaming about it. As a loud yawn seemed to catch her attention, the feline's head turned toward where the clan deputy, Laurelblaze, was currently showing off whatever she could as she welcomed the morning. The apprentice flicked in ear in mild distaste - the only allowed to be flashy should be her. She most certainly had the looks for it, right? The thought of her even being second in terms of appearance or physical strength made her nose crinkle slightly, and she flicked her tail in mild irritation. Sorrelpaw was the best in appearance - she should be the only one who was able to show off her gorgeously patterned coat, not the clan deputy!
A small huff was quick to escape her jaws, although if Laurelblaze happened to look the apprentice's way, she would only offer a sickeningly sweet smile in return. Couldn't have anyone suspecting her of not being genuine, right? Despite that fact that most of her clanmates knew her as a totally stuck-up jerk who either flirted or pranked them just for the kicks of it half the time, she should still be on her 'best' behavior, right? No one could find fault with her if she didn't give them a practical reason to, and that was what she was determined not to do - not to give them a reason. Plus, Icestar couldn't punish her if a cat went up to her and complained of Sorrelpaw's smiling... right? The thought of being punished made her shudder. After a quick second, the apprentice went on to groom her fur, feigning disinterest in what was going on around her. [ @prim ]
prim 08-May-21 11:11 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Sorrelpaw | present
While Laurelblaze did indeed like to be flashy, it was not out of vanity. Her appearance was far from the beauty standard, not with all the scars that lined her body— and noticeably around her face. She had an underbite that left her with a snaggletooth, and her muscular, towering frame made her resemble a beast more so than a feline. When she was younger, she considered her mother to be the most beautiful cat in the world— and she somewhat resembled her in appearance, at least compared to her and her father. Maybe in another life, she’d be a “beauty”, but here she was a rugged warrior, scarred from past battles she’d served in. Reminders that she’d survived them to continue protecting her clan. She’d trade in life and limb if it meant keeping her clanmates safe. That was the strength of her dedication to ThunderClan, her loyalty was unfettering. Besides, the only cat she only really needed to look pretty around was her mate Hollyfrost, and even then, that wasn’t exactly was won over her beloved anyways. They both were spirited she-cats, and they bonded over their loyalty to their clan, took them forever to work out their feelings.
While she’d stood back up, her gaze drifted over towards a young calico molly who’d been sprawled out across a large boulder— grooming her fur. Apprentices these days... Where is her mentor to keep them occupied? perhaps she was speaking from personal experience, as kindhearted as her mentor, Rockfall, was, he was a strict teacher. Though she considered herself better off for it, her work ethic was phenomenal— though she always was an ambitious type. Ever since she was a kit she’d dreamed of becoming the leader of their clan, and she was sure her past self would be proud of how far she’d come... Though there was a lot of hardship along the way. Too much pain, too much death. Perhaps that was why she was so mindful of her clanmates, where they were, what they were doing. It was all a part of her efforts in keeping them safe at all times. Maybe they just didn’t feel the same, that thought scared her. Surely it wasn’t true, though, she might just be reading into it too much. Laurelblaze was a bit... Adamant about her service to the clan, even when she was young. Back then, all her thoughts were to impress the others and to become a cat who could be a potential leader. Though she didn’t do it through the best means all the time. Maybe they weren’t as inclined to recklessness as she was. ”I sure hope you’re not going to spend all day lounging around in camp, it’s a lovely day today!” she called out the young apprentice from afar, deciding to see how she’d react. Laurelblaze always loved to mess around with the younger members of her clan, playing games with them. Be it kits or apprentices, she always strived to get along with them. Perhaps that was partially why she adopted so many kits, and wasn’t stopping anytime soon. @faerielights ♡
Ice 09-May-21 05:30 PM
{ ~ Icestar ~ // (present) }
The sweet newleaf breeze cascaded in gentle waves though the rocky quarry. With it came the pungent scent of wildflower and fresh soil. Icestar inhaled a huge breath, savouring the fresh air from her Highledge perch. The lynx-point stood proudly on the outcrop of rock, letting her paws grip the edge firmly. It was such a pleasant day out with the sun shining and the birds singing in the distance. It was a perfect day for a hunt! The idea having already set on her adamant mind, the ThunderClan leader retreated from her position and made her way down to the clearing of the camp. Life buzzed everywhere. Kits danced around after a stray butterfly. Queens lounged in the shade and shared tongues. Probably gossiping about the latest news, Icestar mused with amusement. A few stray warriors were found taking a break and munching on a rabbit or squirrel. Prey was plentiful enough to afford filling their bellies! Sea-green hues searched for a friend or two, hoping to drag one off with her. @breadstorm (fish/fish's)
Springy 🦤 09-May-21 06:25 PM
Marigolddust - Tigerpaw - Current It took a few moments for the young tom to realize that his feather had been swept up into the wind. Once he did take notice, though, he stiffened and attempted to catch it through raising a milk-touched paw, only to miss it by a few seconds. Getting onto his paws, he went to follow it before he realized that not just his eyes were watching the feather as it flew through the matching color of the sky. His lemon-colored hues caught sight of a brown tabby she-cat, more than likely an apprentice, and realized that she was intent on catching it. He hesitated, one paw slightly raised, as he watched how the hunt progressed. Fortunately, Tigerpaw caught it under a paw. The first questions that came to mind were whether or not he would be returned the feather. Even though he had become an apprentice around two or three moons ago, he still couldn't help but feel like there was a large majority of them who might not have seen or cared where the feather came from and whether or not it belonged to another cat. Even though he could easily spare the feather and just get another one in the future, it was always a disappointment to see that you had something so beautiful in your paws and let it be swept from your grasp, feather or not. Despite his guesses on where the feather might end up, it didn't take long for the stranger apprentice to approach him. When the feather was set down, he reluctantly raised a paw and kept the feather firmly underneath. He made sure sure it wouldn't be swept away again unless some gust of wind stronger than he had felt all New-Leaf captured it before focusing his attention back to the feather saver.
- As always, a nervous smile found itself spreading across his expression. "Yeah..." was all he could think to say to accompany an airy laugh, and he immediately scolded himself over it. What an awkward way to respond to a joke! He hoped this wasn't foretelling the future for the conversation. "Thank you for catching it, by the way." he said, his tail swaying softly behind him as if to wave away the stress that always accompanied a conversation with a new cat. "You're good at hunting, right? You caught that swifter than I expected I would," he added. Well, that wasn't half bad. Perhaps he could save his side of the conversation. @Shade
breadstorm (fish/fish's) 09-May-21 07:15 PM
Strikethroat | @Ice Yawning, the tabby cat padded out of the warrior's den. Strikethroat had wanted to sleep some more, but decided against it, and chose instead to do something with the sunny day. They walked over to the edge of the shade and sat down, looking around. It was no surprise that the camp looked very busy, as the weather was just like a good day in an elder's story. As Strikethroat watched, they began to wash themselves. The sun energized the tired cat a little, and they started longing to go hunting. They were brought back to the time when Strikethroat was still an apprentice, and fondly remembered trying to get on any patrol or hunt they could be on.

"No problem," chirped the youth, wanting to sound casual but unable to keep the merriment from her voice. The wind buffeted her chocolatey fur, giving her a messy look that suited her. tremb 12-May-21 10:55 PM
Wrenkit | Evening had fallen over the ThunderClan camp, half of it ablaze with golden sunlight while the rest succumbed to the shadows. For Wrenkit, this was a wonderful time of day. Soon, the day would be over, and she could be on to the next. Why the hurry to jump to tomorrow? Well, the young brown and white molly was mere days away from reaching her fifth moon, and that meant her sixth moon was so close she could taste it. Aside from that though, dusk was the perfect time to catch bugs. Unlike some kittens, Wrenkit was very good at keeping herself entertained within the walls of the camp. Sure, she couldn’t wait to be an apprentice and be able to explore the territory, but she still found enjoyment in the confinement. When she wasn’t observing her clanmates as they went about their duties, or playing with a moss ball or feather, the young femme could be found chasing bugs. Any sort really. Beetles were great stalking practice, and anything that flew was just a joy to leap around and chase after. Blazing amber eyes locked onto a cricket as it hopped about near the walls of the camp. ”What’s this? An intruder?” Wrenkit sunk low to the ground, wriggling her haunches and propelling herself forwards, pinning the cricket beneath white forepaws. She could feel it wriggling against her paw pads, and she suppressed a giggle. ”That tickles!” She lifted her paws and allowed it to hop a few more paces away, before she pounced for it again. This time, it managed to elude her clumsy paws, but not her pink nose as she nudged it into the air, sending it flying a few tail lengths away. She approached it slowly this time, observing it with her head tilted. The cricket seemed tired, she thought. Gently, Wrenkit nudged the cricket into the undergrowth at the border of the camp, deciding it was best to find a new bug to play with. She didn’t want to kill anything she didn’t plan on eating, and she certainly wasn’t about to eat a cricket. Easily
distracted as any kit, Wrenkit quickly turned her attention to a moth that fluttered half way across the camp, sprinting towards it and leaping into the air below, touching it lightly with her nose. Moths, she had learned, were very delicate. She had accidentally maimed or murdered her fair share, and she knew now it was better to chase it than to try to catch it. He still enjoyed following it around the camp, leaping at it every now and again but avoiding any contact apart from a gentle nose boop. Some of her clanmates may have thought she was getting a bit old for such kit like behavior, but she thought that was nonsense. She was still a kit. She would have plenty of time to be serious when she was an apprentice. Without any duties to fulfill, she was simply keeping herself in shape by playing so much. Besides, the young she kit seemed very aware that one day she wouldn’t have time to play like this, and that kithood should be enjoyed before it was gone. Finally, panting with exhaustion, Wrenkit flopped down outside of the nursery entrance, watching the moth as it disappeared into the evening sky.
@prim
prim 13-May-21 08:33 AM
{Coyotekit} | Wrenkit | present
The shift into nighttime typically meant that he needed to trek back up to the Highledge and head to sleep, but Coyotekit felt a strange fit of restlessness. Typically he was not one to protest going to sleep, he wouldn’t dare defy the will of the ThunderClan leader... His mom. Yet tonight, he just needed to walk around a bit more, spend a few more minutes in camp during twilight hours before he hit the hay. The young tom had been padding around the immediate area surrounding the rocks that led up to the Highledge. His leaf-green gaze flashed lightly under the darkness, like most creatures’ did in low-light conditions. He’d picked up on noise coming from nearby, and a familiar voice belonging to a kit. ”Wrenkit?” he spoke aloud, spotting the she-kit off towards the other side of camp, pouncing on random objects he couldn’t make out from this distance. If he were right, he’d assume she was hunting nocturnal bugs, the crickets always came out around this hour, and he’d seen other kits doing this. He didn’t understand the appeal of potentially getting bug guts smeared all over his paws, but to each their own. He collected bones for a hobby, he shouldn’t be talking anyways.
The pale-furred tabby tom padded towards the familiar kit with an intrigued expression, his long tail held up behind him like a banner. ”What are you doing?” he asked quietly, noticing the small moth his clanmate had recently caught fluttering away from her grasp. So she was hunting bugs... he glanced back down towards the she-kit with an understanding expression. ”Are you staying up too? I can’t sleep right now.” this was a common feeling, he noted, even amongst adults. He did like the nighttime, he never was afraid of the dark. Considering he was getting used to crawling into dark crevices just to reach his bone collections that littered around the dark corners of ThunderClan’s camp to not everyone’s knowledge. Though the young tom was getting bigger now, he was four moons old, and he found himself struggling to find new places to hide his collections in. He was outgrowing them, much like how a child outgrew their toys. A reminder of how he was not going to be a kit forever, not able to keep up with this hobby of his like he could when he was younger. He didn’t like it, though he knew he had to accept and face that reality sooner or later. Kithood did not last forever. ”I can hang out here, if you want. Better than just being by yourself.” normally the young tom wasn’t exactly the most sociable of cats, he didn’t like crowds in the slightest, but he knew Wrenkit. She didn’t judge him for his hobbies, and even helped him, so he figured she wasn’t too bad to have around. A... friend... Maybe? @tremb (SO SORRY I fell asleep before I could type this up )
prim 13-May-21 11:56 AM
{Laurelblaze} | Border Patrol
As the sun made it’s ascent into the morning sky, the deputy of ThunderClan realized it was time to send out sun-high patrols. Already tasking a few others with hunting patrols earlier in the day, she decided to head up a border patrol to renew the scent markers by the WindClan border. Laurelblaze was mostly doing this to ensure that the one badger she and Icestar had encountered there had not returned after she led another patrol to drive it out of the territory. If it had brains, it would know to steer clear of their land, otherwise she and the others were going to have to teach it another harsh lesson. The tortoiseshell only hoped that it was not the case, nobody mentioned any signs of badgers encroaching upon their territory lately, so she was optimistic about their chances. ”Strikethroat, Marigolddust!” she called out to some of the warriors she spotted in camp, before she glanced up at the Highledge with a curious expression. ”...And Icestar! You wanna join in on this patrol I’m heading up?” she called out to the lynx-point femora from below. She ruffled her thick pelt for a moment, before waiting for the two cats she called out to to join her in the clearing. @Ice @breadstorm (fish/fish's) @Springy 🦤 (edited)
tremb 13-May-21 01:44 PM
Wrenkit & Coyotekit | present | @prim Amber eyes met green as a familiar voice greeted her ears, lips curling into a friendly grin. ”Coyotekit! Hi,” she said cheerfully. Wrenkit remembered the last time she had seen the tom she’d been helping him find a new hiding spot for his bone collection. She wondered if he’d managed to keep them hidden this time, or if some pesky adult had located them and tossed them out. She hoped that no one had discovered them, because she thought perhaps Coyotekit would show her his collection one day, and she really wanted to see it. She looked around, checking to see if any cats nearby could be potentially eavesdropping on their conversation. When she spoke, her tone was hushed. ”Has any cat found your bones again? Did you find a good hiding spot?” She inquired, tipping her head to the side. She knew how upset he had looked the last time he’d discovered his bones had been taken, and she didn’t want to see him like that again. She liked it when her friends were happy, and she supposed she and Coyotekit were friends now, right? Any cat who spoke to her more than once was considered a friend in her book. She was momentarily distracted by another insect that fluttered across her field of vision, tail tip twitching excitedly, though she made no move to catch it. She returned her attention to the tom-kit. ”I was chasing bugs,” she admitted. ”I like to practice my stalking and pouncing on them. Plus, they’re sorta cool to look at,” she said. With little than a moon until she’d be made an apprentice, Wrenkit was practicing her hunting skills on anything and everything that she could. Marigolddust had helped her improve her hunters crouch, and she was determined to get even better at it and impress whoever her future mentor would be. She smiled, gaze flitting to the darkening sky above. ”I’ll probably stay awake for a bit longer. I like to watch the stars come out,” she explained, rolling onto her back
so she could gaze more easily at the night sky. A quiet purr rumbled in her chest at bud question, and she nodded eagerly in response. ”I’d like it if you stayed to hang out for a bit. There will be plenty of time for sleeping later,” she mused. Wrenkit would rather be outside than tossing and turning in her nest, and now that she had some company she was content to stay outside until she was tired enough to sleep. ”I’m only a moon away from becoming an apprentice,” she said suddenly, looking up at Coyotekit. ”What do you think it will be like? I’m excited but... I don’t know. A bit nervous, I suppose.” To her it didn’t seem like the other kits got anxious about becoming an apprentice. It was all they talked about, and it seemed like nothing excited them more in the world. Wrenkit was ready to earn her apprentice name and serve her clan, of course, but she wondered what sort of apprentice she would be. Would she live up to her clans expectations? Would she let them down? Could she handle the responsibilities, or learn all of the battle moves? She supposed only time would tell.
Springy 🦤 13-May-21 01:57 PM
Marigolddust - Border Patrol It didn’t take long for the young warrior to arrive at Laurelblaze’s side after being summoned.  His ears were perked and his head slightly tipped to the side.  He had already guessed that this was a patrol, although he wasn’t sure what type quite yet.  A hunting patrol or a border patrol?  Either one made him a little nervous, if only because he was worried about the previous trouble with badgers.  He hadn’t been out of a patrol after the news quite yet, and he never strayed far from the camp once the event had reached his ears.  Badgers were something that he didn’t want to deal with.  Not that he had ever dealt with one before, but he heard lots of stories.  They were large and ferocious, willing to kill a cat for any reason that they found necessary.  He always doubted a single cat could take down one of the beasts, let alone himself.  So, if he completely dodged the risk he decided he would be fine.  This patrol might be the deciding factor on whether or not the badger wasn’t going to return.  Little stories like this always seemed to be given more attention by him than larger ones, such as the Shiny family or Hazelhues.       But, enough of that worried thinking.  From what it seemed like, he would be with another warrior, Laurelblaze, and Icestar on this patrol.  If any badger did come they should be handled… hopefully.  ”I’m here,” he chirped once he had gotten over his thoughts, although it wasn’t likely that he had gone unnoticed until now.  It was an okay day, and not one that he wanted to be ruined by any sour or startling ideas he came up with.

Springy 🦤 13-May-21 02:11 PM

" They tossed the words over their shoulder as they watched the furry, cream-colored cat fume at the silver cat's insult.

Shade 13-May-21 06:34 PM
Tigerpaw didn't seem to notice Marigolddust's lengthy mulling and contemplation. She never did with these things, really. Her infectious grin never faded. In fact, it only grew wider and brighter with the tom warrior's next question. "Laurelblaze," she blurted, just under an ear-splitting chirp. She tried her best to be humble, but what was cooler than being under the wing of the clan's deputy, and future leader? Tigerpaw remember that day not so long ago - only a few moons - when her mentor had been named. She'd been too excited to be intimidated by the giant torbie, being more concerned with either feinting or watching her soul leave her body for StarClan's hunting grounds early. She was already good at hunting, and she'd be a tricky fighter to beat too, with Laurelblaze's guidance up her sleeve. But she refused to give the admirable she-cat all the credit. Tigerpaw cleared her throat and straightened, quickly adding, "But I practice on my own too. All the time, actually." She wanted so badly to show off to him, and paused for a heartbeat to search his honey colored eyes for any hint of interest, then went ahead with her offer anyway. "Hey, you should take me on patrol. I can show you what I can do- You won't be disappointed." Eyes of fuschia rounded in plea. How could you say no to that face? @Springy 🦤
Ice 13-May-21 07:28 PM
{ ~ Icestar ~ // Patrol (present) }
Laurelblaze’s call sent a pleasant chill of excitement verberating through her. She had been anchored in camp this entire morning, chasing down her mischievous kits and getting them out of whatever trouble they had been diving headfirst into. What is with Coyotekit’s weird fascination with bones!? She thought incredulously as she had caught the young tom innocently stashing one away behind the warrior’s den. The silvery-white molly looked up into the heterochromatic gaze of ThunderClan’s deputy. It had been a shame she hadn’t been on the patrol to drive the badger away but the sprain she had gotten from her race with Laurelblaze had sentenced her to a full day in the leader’s den until it got better. ” I’m up for it!” She called out cheerfully, making her way over. Marigolddust and Strikethroat… These three were going to make an interesting combination. @breadstorm (fish/fish's) @prim @Springy 🦤
Sweg 13-May-21 07:28 PM
Sootfang
The bulky tomcat re-entered the camp, feet and face damp from the stream before he dropped the fish off into the fresh kill pile. He trotted a few paces away before sitting down and he licked his paws and claws clean.
prim 13-May-21 07:41 PM
{Laurelblaze} | Border Patrol
They had all gathered together at last, Good, then we can be on our way! she thought with a satisfied grin. She dipped her head to the group in acknowledgement, before she finally spoke up to elucidate them on the situation at hand. "I sent out hunting patrols this morning, but I wanted to lead a quick border patrol out by the stream by the WindClan border. I just want to make sure that badger we drove out earlier this moon hasn't returned. After the walloping we gave it, I highly doubt it's made a return, but you never know with those things." her gaze narrowed for a moment, and her tone grew serious. "Now I don't expect to run into it, but always be on your guard. That being said, just focus on marking the border so it, or it's friends know to stay away." Her stance relaxed as her bushy tail dropped down behind her, her typical, easy-going expression returning to her features as she looked upon her clanmates. This was going to be quick and easy, she hoped, but she was not going to tempt fate. "Let's move out while the sun is still up, shall we?" she nodded to the group as she made an about-face for the camp entrance, leading the way out to the woods through the narrow passageway. @Springy 🦤 @breadstorm (fish/fish's) @Ice
Springy 🦤 13-May-21 08:19 PM
Marigolddust - Border Control This might have been the first patrol that Marigolddust had been assigned to where he knew the majority of the cats.  The only cat he didn’t exactly know well was Strikethroat, which caused a little more anxiety to stir up inside of his chest.  Otherwise, his companions didn’t give him much worry at all.  Maybe some intimidation, but otherwise he was comfortable with who Laurelblaze had chosen.  The small announcement that the deputy shared was what caused him to worry the most.  He was split on whether he should think of this patrol as a relaxed one with little to no worries or one where he had to always stay alert for any dangers to come from any direction.  There didn’t seem to be any inbetween for the tom, and that provided him with far more troubles than he wished it had.  But, he just had to focus on the goal of the patrol: remain a little cautious and do a good job marking the territories to further eliminate the threat.       As Laurelblaze suddenly became serious Marigolddust tensed.  He couldn’t help but stiffen or get nervous when the tortie became so stern with any subject, even if it was a fake expression.  Fortunately it didn’t last all that long, and as she relaxed he did, to.  He aimed his golden hues towards the sky, examining where the sun was.  Squinting, he just gave an upward glance before looking in front to him again and nodding.  Giving himself a small shake as if to shake off some of his nerves, he swiftly padded forwards in pursuit of Laurelblaze, slipping through the entryway with ease and sticking close to the rest of the group.
@breadstorm (fish/fish's) @Ice @prim
prim 13-May-21 08:21 PM
{Coyotekit} | Wrenkit | present
Kits always treated the title of “friend” so loosely, though he figured it couldn’t hurt to not be a complete social recluse from the rest of the clan. Besides, she wasn’t annoying or anything, and seemed genuinely interested in the things he had to say. So... She was alright in his book, he could consider her a friend. ”Nobody’s taken them yet, but I’m having trouble accessing them. I’m getting too big to crawl through the spaces.” that was the truth, the young tom had been going through a growth spurt, and it wasn’t stopping. His legs were starting to get all long and gangly, and he found himself tripping over his paws a lot more than before. He was going to be a lanky cat, that was for sure, he might end up resembling a WindClanner when he was finally grown. Ironic considering the WindClan leader was present for his and his siblings births, not that he remembered it. He was blind and deaf, didn’t even know of her existence. Not yet, anyways. ”So, you’re practicing your hunting skills before you become an apprentice?” it was a pretty logical conclusion, many kits did that just to impress their mentors with their work ethic. They wanted to show off, that they were going to be the greatest apprentice ever trained. Half the kits in the nursery had aspirations of leadership, that they were going to receive their nine lives from StarClan and lead the clan into a new tomorrow. He ought to ask his mother what it was like, he might actually give them a reality check. Not to be a killjoy, but to get them to focus on actually doing something fun for themselves rather than focus on something so... serious, and so, so far away in the future. He might be quiet and reserved, but he could be quite perceptive and knowledgeable if he wanted to be. It was just in his nature, though he mostly concerned himself with guarding his collections of bones while he still could reach his paws in to grab them.
”A moon away, huh? I got two more to go before I’m of age to get apprenticed. Even so, I dunno if my mom is too eager to let my siblings and I go. Don’t wanna go ahead and make her feel old.” he snickered quietly as he stared up at the Highledge. The outcropping wouldn’t be his den for much longer, or ever again. He’d be living in the apprentices’ den, then the warriors’ den, and one day, the elders’ den, if he made it that far. It was weird, and some part of him felt disappointed, he liked waking up high above the rest of camp, looking down from that perch... Though he knew it wouldn’t last forever. He had a lot riding on his shoulders for being the leader’s son, and he was going to prove it to his mother that he and his siblings were ready for their apprenticeships once they were of age. ”I wanna make sure she knows I’ll be okay. I gotta.” @tremb
Springy 🦤 13-May-21 09:47 PM
Marigolddust - Tigerpaw - Current It was definitely a good thing that the apprentice didn’t take much mind to his moments of thought.  He never liked to keep others waiting for him to say something, and believing that she didn’t care gave him confidence.       ”Laurelblaze?” he repeated, startled.  Why had he not expected her mentor to be a cat like Laurelblaze?  Perhaps it was because the idea of any high rank having an apprentice seemed completely unreal to him.  At his own ceremony and others that he had watched he had never really witnessed a cat being apprenticed to Laurelblaze or Icestar.  The only time that he watched a high rank appoint an apprentice was when Fernpaw was made the medicine cat apprentice, which made sense, as he couldn’t see himself ever missing a single one of her ceremonies, even if they wouldn’t share her next one.  She was there a his anywho, even though she hadn’t been one to gain a rank that day.  There was no way that he wouldn’t do the same for her when the time came.  It was odd, the fact that medicine cat apprentices had to wait so long to become a full on medicine cat.  Why couldn’t they gain a rank at the same time as the other apprentices of the clan?       Shaking his head free of the thoughts, he tried to focus all of his attention on the conversation, using the pink-eyed tabby in front of him as an anchor.  ”Laurelblaze must be a good mentor, huh?” he said with a smile.  It seemed like Laurelblaze had a good match here with the apprentice.  Tigerpaw seemed excited, determined, and skilled like he expected Laurelblaze might have been when she was an apprentice, and now, for that matter.  His audits perked when she gave some credit to herself, to.  Oddly enough, Marigolddust c=found his words running more smoothly now that he actually knew about the topic and what he could say.
- He was interested in what words he heard and said enough for his own sentence to run out of his mouth like a stream into a river.  ”I think I heard that Laurelblaze did that when she was an apprentice,” he mentioned, curiosity shimmering in his eyes.  Icestar did pretty good at picking this match, didn’t she?  She seemed like she usually knew who to give what apprentice.       Take her onto a patrol?  Excitement sprang up inside of the ash colored tom at the idea.  He wasn’t exactly the most loving towards the dangers in the forest around which most of the Thunderclanners did their patrols, but his excitement partly came from this.  Because he was too afraid to go very far into the forest alone he often found himself feeling useless inside of camp, sitting around when he felt he should be doing something more beneficial.  He was getting better at gathering up with confidence for things such as solo hunts, but he had yet to fully get into the swing of things.  This could be his opportunity to feel useful.  Although, it was a little worrying that he would end up being the one expected to be the most mature on this patrol.  ”Sure, I’ve been wanting to do a patrol recently, anyways,” he said with a smile, happy to be able to fan the flames of excitement that burned in Tigerpaw’s eyes.

tremb 14-May-21 10:22 PM
Wrenkit & Coyotekit | @prim Wrenkit gave a satisfactory nod when Coyotekit said that his bone stash had yet to be discovered. She was glad that he could still enjoy his collection. His issue with outgrowing the space troubled her, however. She was the type to make another cats problem her own, and would help any cat with anything, even if it didn’t affect her whatsoever. That trait could prove to be an issue for her in the future, but for the time being it didn’t seem to matter. She had helped him once before, and she would gladly do it again if he asked her to. ”Thats no good,” she replied, frowning slightly. ”It’s sort of strange though, isn’t it? How we don’t realize how much we’re growing until we can’t fit into certain places anymore.” She reflected. It was true. The young molly didn’t feel that much larger, but the nursery seemed to grow smaller every day, and even the warriors didn’t seem as large as they once had. The only thing she really noticed was how her legs had grown longer, and how her muscles had strengthened. She didn’t tire out as easily when she played now, and she no longer felt the need for her afternoon naps in the den. Things seemed to change slowly now, but soon everything would be different. She nodded, flashing the tom a grin. ”Yep! I stalk bugs every day, they’re great practice! I want to be able to catch something on my very first hunt when I’m made an apprentice,” she explained. She knew that hunting successfully on an apprentices first day wasn’t that extraordinary, but it was still an accomplishment Wrenkit could be proud of. She didn’t have aspirations of being the greatest warrior in ThunderClan, but she did want to make herself and her clanmates proud. She wanted to be good. ”I also do it for fun, of course. I get bored playing by myself sometimes and bugs are... interesting,” she concluded with a little shrug. For some reason, Wrenkit felt a small pang of sadness when Coyotekit said
that he had two moons until he reached his apprenticeship. She enjoyed the toms company, and he was one of very few friends that she had. She’d hoped that they’d be sharing the apprentices den at the same time, but she supposed she could wait a moon for him. Wrenkit hoped that he would still be her friend, even when she was an apprentice and he wasn’t. Of course, it was silly to think that one moons age difference would have any affect on their friendship, but those were just the things that Wrenkit worried about. Her amber eyes rounded with sympathy. ”I’m sure she will miss you being in the den with her, but I bet you’re going to make her very proud.” Wrenkit could imagine the leader would be very pleased to see her kits on their way to becoming strong warriors of the clan. She flicked Coyotekit gently with her tail tip, smiling softly. ”You’re going to be great.”

Springy 🦤 15-May-21 01:20 PM
Marigolddust - Tigerpaw - Current Marigolddust couldn’t help but smile a the statement “she’s big”.  Laurelblaze was the largest cat that he had ever met or seen, but he found it amusing that that was what Tigerpaw mentioned.  He himself thought that her size was a little intimidating, considering the fact that she was twice his size in every aspect; size, courage, personality, skills, etc.  It was pretty awesome that she was on the side of Thunderclan, though.  There was no doubt that if she was on a side that he might oppose in the future he would give in the fight immediately.  Who would want to fight her, anyways?       It was easy to see how excited Tigerpaw got when he mentioned that Laurelblaze had done what Tigerpaw does now.  He hadn’t expected her to seem so surprised, especially since he would have thought that she would have already heard about it, since Laurelblaze was her mentor and all.  He had never actually been told about how Skycloud felt about her own apprentichood or how she trained though… So what reason did Laurelblaze have to?  Did the two practice the same way?  Did everyone other than him practice on their own time?  Fernpaw as always practicing, and he had no clue how the apprentices or warriors he knew dealt with apprentice hood.  Perhaps he didn’t go through apprentice hood correctly.  He never did think that he was any better at being a warrior than any other cat.  Maybe he should try to fit in more hunting trips or patrols, even if he had to gather the confidence to do so first.  He distracted himself by raising and grooming his paw briefly.  He didn’t need to think about things like this, especially since he was going to go on a patrol now.  This could be good practice, right?
-     Standing, he gave himself a little shake before following behind the apprentice’s dark tabbied form.  With a gentle smile still displayed across his features, he twitched his ear and readied himself mentally for some hunting.  Although Tigerpaw would be doing the majority of it, as she was the one who was supposed to be showing him what she could do, he felt that it would be disrespectful to go out on a patrol and not return with something for the clan.  It took him only a few paces to pad through the exit close behind Tigerpaw.

prim 16-May-21 11:48 PM
{Coyotekit} | Wrenkit | present
It was true, he wasn’t some bumbling kitten fattened from the milk he’d been sustained from. He wasn’t lethargic from overeating, napping only when he truly felt exhaustion. He began to actually start looking like a cat, he’d shed away his soft kitten fluff as if it were the down feathers of a baby chick. Plus, he’d long since noticed how he’d grown taller, that was rather obvious. He’d begun to tower over other kits around his age. ”Yeah, I’m lucky I don’t have to worry about hitting my head on the tops of den entrances and stuff. The den in the Highledge is pretty big, at least for a few cats.” it was adequate for a leader and her family, it seemed, but to house multiple warriors? It wasn’t very practical for that purpose. One little aspect he should feel grateful for as the leader’s child.
His tail flickered as the she-kit gave her reasoning for spending her night hunting bugs. That was her motive? It was a pretty lofty goal for most apprentices, he’d heard most failed on their very first hunt. It was harder than they thought, and he didn’t believe that practicing on bugs was a very effective form of practice— but what did he know? He was just the kit who also happened to be a bone collector, he wasn’t exactly striving for greatness. Coyotekit preferred a quieter existence within the clan, being left to his own devices that did not cause anyone else harm. He’d leave the ambitious attitudes to his peers, it was too much excitement for him anyways. ”Well, I hope it helps you on your first day. That is a pretty hard thing to achieve on your first hunt, or so I’ve heard.” his shoulders slumped in a small shrug, though he sounded genuine enough in his wishes for her good fortune— at least more so than usual. He did sound awfully formal for a kit, though he only did it mostly to be polite, unless someone did stir up his temper. If he was annoyed enough, he could be quite the little hot-head and get quite sassy. Luckily, Wrenkit hadn’t gotten on his bad side, he was quite creative with his rather colorful insults. Lots of time alone spent eavesdropping allowed him to expand his vocabulary. Not that he really used it much, he just had them in his arsenal, just in case ”Well, I’m sure she’ll also be happy she’ll have her den back for herself. Sharing it with seven kittens isn’t easy, I’m sure. I try to not get in her way that much, she already has a lot on her plate, being a leader and all.” truly, he did not understand the scale and depth of his mother’s work as the ThunderClan leader. There was so much he didn’t know that went on in that den, meetings, decisions that would forever affect the clan. He was blissfully unaware, yet he practically called it home. @tremb
Ice 18-May-21 09:48 PM

Her white-mittened paws flexed against the quarry ground. Unfortunately, Icestar doubted they’d be able to catch something in this weather. lynn 19-May-21 12:04 AM
aspenpaw | tigerpaw | present @Shade Dim light filtered into the apprentice den, the sun peppering kisses on each of the young cat’s pelts. The atmosphere was slightly humid and chilled from the previous night’s gentle rainfall. To Aspenpaw, it was almost as if the earth was letting out a long, cool, sigh of relief. Stretching her tired bones, the dull tabby molly dragged herself into a seated position, eyes lazily scanning her surroundings as she blinked the drowsiness from them. With a low sigh, she managed to haul herself out of the den, making sure to shove a certain brown cat awake as she departed. Outside of the den, the cool air worked it’s way through the tall apprentice’s fur, relieving her of the uncomfortable heat trapped in her pelt from sleeping near so many warm bodies. She groomed herself and stretched as she awaited Tigerpaw to exit the den too. They had come to a recent conclusion of sorts; they would help each other with their training, specifically the hunting portion. It was unorthodox, and certainly not a regular occurrence by any means, but Aspenpaw knew one thing: without the other molly, she was a terrible hunter. Of course, this meant she spent more hours training, but that was nothing to the she-cat. She didn’t have many friends to begin with. Well, she didn’t have any at all. Though, she supposed, now she had Tigerpaw. With that thought, her pupils narrowed. Now she had Tigerpaw. Suppressing a groan, the feline’s ears folded back. Her tangerine gaze focused onto the skyline with fatal intensity. She’d make this work. She had to.
Shade 19-May-21 11:43 AM
Tigerpaw was soundly asleep per usual, snoring the day away even as the first sheets of milky dawn light spilled through the trees and over the cliffs of camp. The apprentice den, a half burrow at the bottom of Icestar's ledge path, remained dark. Cozy as it was, it was never by her own volition that the young brown tabby found her way into consciousness. Her jeweled head was lolling over the edge of her nest when Aspenpaw gave her a hard prod in the side, dampening the moss with drool and hot, sleepy breath. The dozing she-cat snorted sharply as though she might wake up, but instead rolled the other way without even a show of visionary pink. Perhaps she rolled too far. Another unfortunate apprentice gave an irritable groan and shoved Tigerpaw's limp body off their turf. Tigerpaw whimpered drowsily and finally pushed herself upright on sore forearms, quivering shoulder muscles showing off developing tone beneath cocoa stripes as she stretched them. A mighty yawn skipped from her jaws and she smacked her lips as she finally peeled her gooey eyes open and panned the dim den. Most of the nests were still laden with curled up bodies, flanks rising and falling steadily, but one silhouette waited just beyond the bushy entrance. Tigerpaw grinned mildly with interest and weaved her way out to join the familiar lanky figure. She raked her body along the reinforcing thorns that arched the den entrance, arching her back with pleasure as she did so, and came to stand beside her newest friend. "Did Snowstorm leave already?" she asked as she paralleled herself to her peer, surveying the still blueish camp. Laurelblaze was always busy in the mornings doling out patrols. The last group could be seen slipping out of sight into the territory while others nodded to the deputy and dispersed. They look so important... Tigerpaw thought with envy, gazing after them. @lynn

Wrenkit & Coyotekit | @prim Wrenkit replied with a simple shrug of her shoulders, a smile still adorning her features as usual. Even if she didn’t hunt successfully on her first day, she wouldn’t let it bring her down. She’d never let something so small ruin her first day as an apprentice, and yet, she remained very hopeful still that she would be able to do it. And if not? That was okay, too. She was a fast learner, and was sure that she could use her mistakes to improve her skills rather quickly. She chuckled softly, batting at a small mosquito as it buzzed by the pair of kits. Easily distracted as ever. ”Yeah, I suppose it is a pretty big goal. I won’t be upset if I don’t catch anything, but I’ll be so excited if I do.” She explained. ”I’m just excited to bring food home for my clanmates. I always watch the warriors and apprentices come back with jaws full of prey, and it seems like a nice feeling,” she added, her smile widening a bit. She nodded at his next words, imagining what it would be like to have so many siblings. What a pawful that many kittens must be for one cat, and the leader nonetheless. ”Being the leader of an entire clan sounds very... intimidating. Icestar is quite good at it, though.” Granted, the young kit wouldn’t know the first thing about being a leader, but from her perspective it seemed like Icestar did a great job. The clan was happy, healthy, and well fed. For Wrenkit, ThunderClan was the best place in the whole forest to be. Of course, she wouldn’t know any better even if it wasn’t. She wouldn’t know anything about the other clans until she was apprenticed, besides old nursery tales of course, which mostly revolved around ShadowClan and how evil they were. She tipped her head slightly to one side as her mind began to wander, and she once more found herself thinking about what apprenticeship would be like. ”What are you looking forward to the most about becoming an apprentice?” She inquired.
Sure, she had an entire moon to go and Coyotekit had two, but certainly he must be excited for the day as well, right? (So sorry this took me so long, it’s been a crazy week)

- ───────── CARDINALSPARK !! // WARRIOR OF THUNDERCLAN

Quite close, as a matter of fact. He could tell that it wasn’t merely a clanmate passing by, as the presence of another remained in the same spot. tremb 21-May-21 07:56 PM
Juniperpaw & Tigerpaw | @Shade Pale dawn light filtered through the trees, casting a light golden glow into the ThunderClan camp. As usual, Juniperpaw was one of the first to make an appearance out of the apprentices den. Always eager to be the first one hunting, the first one training. The silver tabby’s many ambitions included being an impeccable fighter, and that meant spending as much time as possible in the training hollow with his mentor and fellow apprentices. Nothing beat the feeling of perfecting a new battle move before any of the others, and as self absorbed as he could be, Juniperpaw loved the attention it earned him. Some might call it arrogance, but he preferred to call it confidence. He believed that there was nothing he couldn’t perfect with practice, and so far that had proven to be true. If any cat didn’t appreciate his occasional bragging, it wasn’t like they had to listen, right? Jaws parting in a yawn, the tom licked a large black paw and swiped it over his ears a few times before turning to smooth down some ruffled silver fur on his flank. Already, he was pleased with how his muscles had began to develop under his thick, long coat of silver and black. Each day he could feel himself getting stronger, getting closer to becoming the formidable warrior he so desired to be. He knew it was frowned upon, but he found himself hoping he got to be apart of battle soon. Of course he didn’t want the clans to fight, but he wanted the chance to show off his newly learned skills in a real battle scenario, with claws unsheathed. He’d show any other clan apprentices that ThunderClan was not a clan to be trifled with. As far as he was concerned, they had the strongest warriors in the forest, and he was on his way to becoming one of them.
prim 21-May-21 08:29 PM
{Coyotekit} | Wrenkit | past I
He had to pause to think on the question for a moment. Coyotekit didn’t tend to look too far into the future, and he had a habit of getting so engrossed in his current daily habits that he really did not have the time nor the energy to really devote any mental capacity towards such a subject. Needless to say, he didn’t exactly have a plan, nor really anything he looked forward to most. Sure, he was happy he’d be able to enjoy newfound freedoms, but that was what everyone else looked forward to. Usually everyone had one unique thing they wanted to do once they received their promotion... Right now, he really didn’t have a clue as to what he enjoyed most. In all honesty, he was slowly becoming a bit more disinterested in collecting bones at the moment. Mostly because others around him were discouraging him from doing so, but he also felt as if he’d exhausted the subject. When he was younger, he was hoping he’d have more places to hide them out in the woods, though now he was trying to think of ways he could branch out. ”I... I don’t know.” he murmured quietly, his ears pinning back against his skull for a brief moment. His neutral expression had turned to a more crestfallen one. He figured he’d just be focused on training, and avoiding doing anything that might incite his mother’s anger. He was a well-behaved kit, kept his nose clean aside from causing minor inconveniences whenever his bone collections were discovered. ”I... I’ll likely just be doing what I need to do. I dunno what there is I really want to do. Maybe get to see the lake?” even he sounded half-hearted about that possibility, these were just from on the spot. He’d have to take time to truly plan out his future. Something he just now realized he’d neglected handling. Kits aren’t kits forever, you’re seeing it now, Coyotekit, he’d stared down at his oversized paws for a moment, letting out a small sigh. (edited)
This was a bit... distressing for him. Even if he wasn’t outwardly showing a huge reaction of it. @tremb
lynn 22-May-21 11:54 AM
aspenpaw | tigerpaw | past @Shade The duller of the two flicked an ear at the other’s words. ”I don’t know. Maybe? It doesn’t matter.” Aspenpaw huffed out, her gaze peering towards the camp entrance. Glancing towards the few cats in the clearing, the brown molly sucked in a sharp breath. ”There’s an opening behind the den we can leave camp from. I don’t think we should just saunter out of camp in front of everyone.” Her intense gaze returned to Tigerpaw and she nodded curtly to the cheery she-cat before padding around the den and slipping between a small opening in the thicket that densely surrounded ThunderClan camp. The apprentice’s slender form emerged on the other side of the bushes, pupils narrowing as she tried to recall where she was. Aspenpaw had been an apprentice for 3 moons already, so she knew the territory fairly well, but she had never left camp from this point before. After a moment of thinking the molly’s expression relaxed and she tossed her head back while she waited for her clan-mate. (sorry for the short and kinda meh reply!!)
